div1.p: Kean describes Reed's illness, death, and funeral.

div1.head: Recollection of Walter Reed's death, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, [[19--]]
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
Reed's Death
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
div1.p:
Reeds attack began Nov 12
but he did not go to bed for
several days - was better on the
15th On that evening I dined
there to meet Gorgas & he was
not able to come to the table
16th pulse unusual temp not
over 99.5- 17th R. had an
uncomfortable night & B. oper-
ated this morning- appendix
tightly adherent behind caput
coli with small abscess-
caput coli inflamed & stiff dark color
B. drained & walled off
abscess with guaze & pre-
dicted slughing & a fecal
fistula- Saw him on 18th
he was nauseated & much
depressed- On aft of 19th
Pulse 138 temp 102- very nervous
& ill-

Friday aft did not see R as he was
asleep, that night he became
worse; Paeking taken out
Sat- & fecal fistula found
peritinitis well marked-
I saw him with Blossom
Sat night, he is conscious
but flighty & with cold
extremities, condition evidently
hopeless- He knew me &
talked rationally- told me
to take B. home-

He died at 2.15 am Sunday
Nov 23rd 1902-

The funeral was with military
honors & was on Tuesday
Nov 25- Pall bearers were
Dewitt, LaGarde, Davis, McCaw,
Kean, Banister- from St Thomas
church- The members of the
Army & the Navy Med Schools
attended in uniform in a body
& the Profs & many students
of Columbian Univ- Profs Welch
Osler Flexner & many general
officers of the Army-
